Welcome To The E-Library

   

Novels

Harry Potter (series)

J.K. Rowling

Source: Click For Details

It is a story about Harry Potter, an orphan brought up by his aunt and uncle because his parents were killed when he was a baby. Harry is unloved by his uncle and aunt but everything changes when he is invited to join Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry and he finds out he's a wizard.

A Fine Balance

Rohinton Mistry

Source: Click For Details

Set in "an unidentified city" in India, initially in 1975 and later in 1984 during the turmoil of The Emergency, the book focuses on four characters from varied backgrounds – Dina Dalal, Ishvar Darji, his nephew Omprakash Darji, and the young student Maneck Kohlah – who come together and develop a bond.

Great Expectations

Charles Dickens

Source: Click For Details

Great Expectations charts the progress of Pip from childhood through often painful experiences to adulthood, as he moves from the Kent marshes to busy, commercial London, encountering a variety of extraordinary characters ranging from Magwitch, the escaped convict, to Miss Havisham, locked up with her unhappy past and living with her ward, the arrogant, beautiful Estella.

Black Beauty

Anna Sewell

Source: Click For Details

The bittersweet saga of the handsome colt that is wrenched from a happy country home and almost worked to death as a London cab horse is adapted for easy reading. Large type, short chapters, and expressive art make this a must for all animal lovers.

A Christmas Carol

Charles Dickens

Source: Click For Details

Introduction and Afterword by Joe Wheeler To bitter, miserly Ebenezer Scrooge, Christmas is just another day. But all that changes when the ghost of his long-dead business partner appears, warning Scrooge to change his ways before it's too late.

Little Women

Louisa May Alcott

Source: Click For Details

Generations of readers young and old, male and female, have fallen in love with the March sisters of Louisa May Alcott’s most popular and enduring novel, Little Women.

Around the World in Eighty Days

Jules Verne

Source: Click For Details

One night in the reform club, Phileas Fogg bets his companions that he can travel across the globe in just eighty days. Breaking the well-established routine of his daily life, he immediately sets off for Dover with his astonished valet Passepartout.

The Complete Works of Sherlock Holmes

Arthur Conan Doyle

Source: Click For Details

Adventures of Sherlock Holmes : A scandal in Bohemia ; The red-headed league ; A case of identity ; The Boscombe Valley mystery ; The five orange pips ; The man with the twisted lip ; The adventure of the blue carbuncle ;

Catch-22

Joseph Heller

Source: Click For Details

Fifty years after its original publication, Catch-22 remains a cornerstone of American literature and one of the funniest—and most celebrated—books of all time. In recent years it has been named to “best novels” lists by Time, Newsweek, the Modern Library, and the London Observer.

A Thousand Splendid Suns by Khaled Hosseini

Khaled Hosseini

Source: Click For detials

The primary theme in the novel A Thousand Splendid Suns is the rights of women, especially under the Taliban. Mariam and Laila grow up during regimes that are not oppressive.

Short stories

Indian Literature

Source: Click For Details

The term "Indian literature" is sometimes used more loosely to refer to literature of the Indian diaspora (people of Indian origin living outside of India).

The Monk Who Sold His Ferrari

Robin S. Sharma

Source: Click For Details

This inspiring tale provides a step-by-step approach to living with greater courage, balance, abundance, and joy. A wonderfully crafted fable, The Monk Who Sold His Ferrari tells the extraordinary story of Julian Mantle, a lawyer forced to confront the spiritual crisis of his out-of-balance life.

Chicken Soup for the Indian Spiritual Soul

Jack Canfield

Source: Click For Details

Physician, friend, guide, mentor, saviour - there's more to a good doctor than that plaque on his wall or the best bedside manner. This is Westland tipping its hat to all those men and women of medicine who bravely don theirs to perform all those roles for us.

Who Will Cry When You Die?

Robin S. Sharma

Source: Click For Details

Would you like to replace that empty feeling inside you with a deep sense of peace, passion, and purpose? Are your hoping that your life will not only be successful but significant? Are you ready to have the very best within you shine through and create a rich legacy in the process?

Many Lives, Many Masters

Brian L. Weiss

Source: Click For Details

The true story of a prominent psychiatrist, his young patient, and the past-life therapy that changed both their lives. As a traditional psychotherapist, Dr. Brian Weiss was astonished and skeptical when one of his patients began recalling past-life traumas that seemed to hold the key to her recurring nightmares and anxiety attacks.

The Secret

Rhonda Byrne

Source: Click For Details

Fragments of a Great Secret have been found in the oral traditions, in literature, in religions, and philosophies throughout the centuries. For the first time, all the pieces of The Secret come together in an incredible revelation that will be life-transforming for all who experience it.

The Great Stories of Munshi Premchand

Munshi Premchand

Source: Click For Details

Munshi Premchand (Hindi: मुंशी प्रेमचंद) was an Indian writer famous for his modern Hindustani literature. He is one of the most celebrated writers of the Indian subcontinent,and is regarded as one of the foremost Hindustani writers of the early twentieth century.

The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People

Stephen R. Covey

Source: Click For Details

Internationally renowned leadership authority and bestselling author Stephen R. Covey presents a personal hands-on companion to the landmark The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People , which has become a touchstone for individuals, families, and businesses around the world.

Tuesdays with Morrie

Mitch Albom

Source: Click For Details

Maybe it was a grandparent, or a teacher or a colleague. Someone older, patient and wise, who understood you when you were young and searching, and gave you sound advice to help you make your way through it.

The Inheritance of Loss

Kiran Desai

Source: Click For Details

In a crumbling, isolated house at the foot of Mount Kanchenjunga in the Himalayas lives an embittered judge who wants only to retire in peace, when his orphaned granddaughter, Sai, arrives on his doorstep.

Biography

Wings of Fire

A.P.J. Abdul Kalam

Source: Click For Details

Avul Pakir Jainulabdeen Abdul Kalam, the son of a little-educated boat-owner in Rameswaram, Tamil Nadu, had an unparalleled career as a defence scientist, culminating in the highest civilian award of India, the Bharat Ratna.

Long Walk to Freedom

Nelson Mandela

Source: Click For Details

Nelson Mandela is one of the great moral and political leaders of our time: an international hero whose lifelong dedication to the fight against racial oppression in South Africa won him the Nobel Peace Prize and the presidency of his country.

American prometheus

Kai Bird , Martin J. Sherwin

Source: Click For Details

American Prometheus is the first full-scale biography of J. Robert Oppenheimer, "father of the atomic bomb," the brilliant, charismatic physicist who led the effort to capture the awesome fire of the sun for his country in time of war.

The Story of My Life

Helen Keller

Source: Click For Details

When she was 19 months old, Helen Keller (1880–1968) suffered a severe illness that left her blind and deaf. Not long after, she also became mute. Her tenacious struggle to overcome these handicaps-with the help of her inspired teacher, Anne Sullivan-is one of the great stories of human courage and dedication

Autobiography of a Yogi

Paramahansa Yogananda

Source: Click For Details

Autobiography of a Yogi is one of the best-selling spiritual biographies of all time. The book is not merely read it is treasured and cherished by millions of spiritual seekers throughout the world.

The Accidental Prime Minister

Sanjaya Baru

Source: Click For Details

In 2004 Sanjaya Baru left a successful career as chief editor of the Financial Express to join Manmohan Singh as his media adviser.

Barack Obama - The Great Speeches

Barack Obama

Source: Click For Details

This inludes the Inaugural speech, the election night victory speech and several other pivotal speeches by the President.

The Success Principles:

Jack Canfield , Janet Switzer

Source: Click For Details

Jack Canfield, cocreator of the phenomenal bestselling Chicken Soup for the SoulÂ® series, turns to the principles he's studied, taught, and lived for more than 30 years in this practical and inspiring guide that will help any aspiring person get from where they are to where they want to be.

The Inner Edge:

Richard A. Wedemeyer

Source: Click For Details

Vision and clarity in work and life is the focus and outcome of The Inner Edge. This intuitive and insightful guide will take you truly inside yourself for the first time, showing you how to make constructive and empowering changes by tapping into previously unknown resources of balance, congruity, and fulfillment.

A Brief History of Time

Stephen Hawking

Source: Click For Details

A landmark volume in science writing by one of the great minds of our time, Stephen Hawking’s book explores such profound questions as: How did the universe begin—and what made its start possible?

Carrer ralated

Getting the students to read

Source: Click For Details

Are you a teacher looking for a new way to inspire a love of book reading in your students? Or have you already introduced Goodreads to your students and are interested in learning how other teachers are using it into their classroom? We've got your cheat sheet of teacher tips here!

Thorns to competition

Arindam Chaudhuri

Source: Click For Details

When magic has gone the world, and a vicious king rules for his throne of glass, an assassin comes to the castle. She does not come to kill, but to win her freedom.

Your PhD companion

Nick Green

Source: Click For Details

This book guides you through doctoral study from the student's point of view - the challenges, pitfalls, and ups and downs that you're likely to encounter in the course of your PhD. Inside you'll find: - Advice on doing research

The art of study

Vijay Agrawal

Source: Click For Details

This book provides a new and alternative approach on how to study. The book shares perspectives and techniques which will help the reader gain a better understanding of how thought works and will stimulate the readers’ brain.

High performance hiring

Robert W. Wendover

Source: Click For Details

A lot has changed when it comes to hiring today - the importance of diversity, the use of e-mail and other technology, and the sheer size of the applicant pool. But the process for success is still the same. Announcing openings.

Great by choice

James C. Collins

Source: Click For Details

Ten years after the worldwide bestseller Good to Great , Jim Collins returns withanother groundbreaking work, this time to ask: why do some companies thrive inuncertainty, even chaos, and others do not?

Tuition classes

Akshay Chopra

Source: Click For Details

There is no denying the fact that education is a must for moral, social and financial development in the human life. Therefore, the level and quality of education is a major concern both for the parents as well as the governing bodies.

How to deal with stress

Richard Banks

Source: Click For Details

This book will walk you through precisely why, how, and what you need to do to stop worrying and start living your life. Nearly 800 million people worldwide experience mental illness. Some of the most prominent adverse mental conditions include stress, anxiety, and depression.

Read faster recall more

C Stevenson

Source: Click For Details

Why reading faster helps you learn more? 7 Reasons Why Speed Reading Is Good For Your Brain Speed reading challenges our brains to perform at a higher level. When you train your brain to be able to take in information faster, other areas of your brain will also improve such as your memory.

Excellence in education

Cyril Taylor

Source: Click For Details

A thorough examination of the characteristics belonging to a high-performing school, this book is written by the Chairman of the Specialist Schools Trust and the education advisor to the Prime Minister, Tony Blair.

Most recommend of books

To Kill a Mockingbird

Harper Lee

Source: Click For Details

The unforgettable novel of a childhood in a sleepy Southern town and the crisis of conscience that rocked it. "To Kill A Mockingbird" became both an instant bestseller and a critical success when it was first published in 1960.

1984

George Orwell

Source: Click For Details

Among the seminal texts of the 20th century, Nineteen Eighty-Four is a rare work that grows more haunting as its futuristic purgatory becomes more real. Published in 1949, the book offers political satirist George Orwell's nightmarish vision of a totalitarian, bureaucratic world and one poor stiff's attempt to find individuality.

Pride and Prejudice

Jane Austen

Source: Click For Details

Since its immediate success in 1813, Pride and Prejudice has remained one of the most popular novels in the English language. Jane Austen called this brilliant work "her own darling child" and its vivacious heroine, Elizabeth Bennet, "as delightful a creature as ever appeared in print."

The Lord of the Rings

J.R.R. Tolkien

Source: Click For Details

In ancient times the Rings of Power were crafted by the Elven-smiths, and Sauron, the Dark Lord, forged the One Ring, filling it with his own power so that he could rule all others. But the One Ring was taken from him, and though he sought it throughout Middle-earth, it remained lost to him.

The Great Gatsby

F. Scott Fitzgerald

Source: Click For Details

The Great Gatsby, F. Scott Fitzgerald's third book, stands as the supreme achievement of his career. This exemplary novel of the Jazz Age has been acclaimed by generations of readers.

Moby-Dick

Herman Melville

Source: Click For Details

So Melville wrote of his masterpiece, one of the greatest works of imagination in literary history. In part, Moby-Dick is the story of an eerily compelling madman pursuing an unholy war against a creature as vast and dangerous and unknowable as the sea itself.

The Catcher in the Rye

J.D. Salinger

Source: Click For Details

Fleeing the crooks at Pencey Prep, he pinballs around New York City seeking solace in fleeting encounters—shooting the bull with strangers in dive hotels, wandering alone round Central Park, getting beaten up by pimps and cut down by erstwhile girlfriends.

Gods and Kings

Lynn Austin

Source: Click For Details

Though born the second son of King Ahaz, Hezekiah is not protected from his father's perverted attempts to gain the favor of the idol Molech. Terrified and powerless at the foot of Molech's altar, Hezekiah encounters for the first time the one true God of his royal ancestry, Yahweh.

Jane Eyre

Charlotte Bronte

Source: Click For Details

Charlotte Brontë tells the story of orphaned Jane Eyre, who grows up in the home of her heartless aunt, enduring loneliness and cruelty.

The Chronicles of Narnia

C.S. Lewis

Source: Click For Details

Journeys to the end of the world, fantastic creatures, and epic battles between good and evil—what more could any reader ask for in one book? The book that has it all is The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, written in 1949 by Clive Staples Lewis.
